summary: This FBI document details an investigation into Alfredo Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, who attempted to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein for $50,000. The FBI planned an undercover operation to record Rodriguez and complete the transaction, noting his actions constituted obstruction of justice.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: A former employee of Jeffrey Epstein who was contacted by an FBI source in August 2009. He was attempting to sell documents pertinent to a civil lawsuit against Epstein for $50,000, despite having been served a federal subpoena to provide them.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The financier who is the defendant in a civil lawsuit brought by four female individuals. His former employee, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed documents related to this case.

persons.name: Frank Navas
persons.context: An FBI agent (MM) from the Miami field office whose email is listed in the document's administrative details.

persons.name: Michael J. Donohoe
persons.context: An FBI agent (MM) listed in the administrative approval section for the consensual monitoring operation.

persons.name: Paul Santino
persons.context: Identified as a confidential source in the context of the investigation, possibly involved in the initial contact or setup.

connections.description: Rodriguez was a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez was contacted by the confidential source, Paul Santino, in August 2009 regarding the documents.

events.title: Initial Contact Regarding Epstein Documents
events.description: Confidential source Paul Santino contacted Alfredo Rodriguez, a former Epstein employee, who revealed he had documents related to a civil suit against Epstein and wanted $50,000 for them.

events.title: FBI Authorization for Undercover Operation
events.description: The FBI drafted and authorized a plan for an undercover employee (UCE) to meet with Alfredo Rodriguez, record the conversation, and complete the transaction for the documents to gather evidence of obstruction of justice.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein for $50,000 in August 2009.
Rodriguez had already been served a federal subpoena compelling him to turn over the documents, making his attempt to sell them a potential obstruction of justice.
The FBI authorized an undercover operation involving consensual recording (body recorder and CCTV) to capture Rodriguez in the act of selling the subpoenaed documents.
The document indicates the investigation was approved by high-ranking officials and was not considered a matter of national security.
The identities of the FBI source and the four female plaintiffs in the civil suit are redacted in the document.
